results.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
results.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.
description_for_label:

He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

results.title: Life
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Johnston, Mandy Walker, Elisa Argenzio, Australian Film Commission and Rough Trade Pictures
results.brief_description: Johnston’s debut feature following on from his award winning shorts ‘Night Out’ and ‘Eternity’, is a dynamic re-visioning of actor/playwright John Brumpton’s theatre piece “Containment” that focused on the situation of inmates in the segregated HIV positive section of an Australian prison. To describe Johnston’s beautifully composed, movingly rendered, emotionally shattering film as ‘an AIDS prison drama’ denies it the full range and reach of its compelling grip on any number of wider issues and universal concerns. Brumpton forcefully fleshes out the lead role of quick-tempered hardened Des, a crim who tests positive and is sent to T2 division. His relationship with his cell-mate Ralph is vividly evoked via subliminal flashbacks and interaction between themselves and amongst the other inmates of T2. Photography, Mandy Walker. Cast: John Brumpton, David Tredinnick, Robert Morgan, Belinda McClory, Noel Jordan.

results.title: Worse than Xmas
results.creator_credit: Julie Harris, Mandy Walker and Joanne Aslanis
results.brief_description: Waitress Angela (Kaarin Fairfax) rushes home to save a doomed relationship. When she fails, she agrees with her neighbour that Easter is the worst time of year, even worse than Christmas. The film follows the funny and inevitable diversions that Angela takes to make it through the breakup and start dating again.

results.title: What the Water Gave Me

video_links.name: Florence + The Machine - What The Water Gave Me

constellations_other.name: From gallery to screen
constellations_other.description: Explore how famous films, videogames and music videos have taken their cue from the art of the past.

results.description: The music video for ‘What the Water Gave Me’ intersperses footage of Florence + the Machine’s studio recording sessions with kaleidoscope shots of Welch performing the song, evoking the crashing of waves and reflective quality of water.
description_for_label: The music video for ‘What the Water Gave Me’ intersperses footage of Florence + the Machine’s studio recording sessions with kaleidoscope shots of Welch performing the song, evoking the crashing of waves and reflective quality of water.

results.title: Zoomfilm
results.brief_description: An experimental film dedicated to the “blink”. Dynamic abstractions (created through use of prodigious optical printing and directly working the film frame) investigate the nature of human optics. Music by Maurizio Kagel.

results.title: Zoo babies: observing things about us
results.brief_description: Designed to teach young children to observe more carefully the things about them. This film compares the habits and physical characteristics of various baby animals at the zoo. Animals studied include monkeys, gnus, lions, peacocks, alligators and bears.

results.title: Zoo animals in rhyme
results.brief_description: Amusing rhymes tell us something about zoo animals children love most - the lion, monkey, elephant, kangaroo, giraffe, bear and many others. A basis for storytelling, vocabulary building, rhyme making, and many related activities. Also brings to the class-room elementary science concepts about animal life.

results.title: Zoo
results.brief_description: Visual essay comparing people and animals at a zoo. Using a ‘candid camera’ technique, Haanstra concentrates on commonly shared facial expressions and physical gestures such as eating and sleeping. Accompanied by a jazz music soundtrack but no spoken commentary.
results.description: Visual essay comparing people and animals at a zoo. Using a ‘candid camera’ technique, Haanstra concentrates on commonly shared facial expressions and physical gestures such as eating and sleeping. Accompanied by a jazz music soundtrack but no spoken commentary.

results.title: Zonation
results.creator_credit: H Scales and Sydney Scientific Film Society
results.brief_description: A group of university students study the zonation pattern of animals and plants on a marine rock platform, and the various physical and biological factors contributing to their distribution. At the highest tide level are blue periwinkles; then the barnacle zone, the worm zone and at low tide level, the cunjevoizone and then kelps. The ways in which various creatures protect themselves against dessication from sun and wind and against being washed off the rocks are shown.
